events.text: The foyer was sick with the smell of things bought and never used, luxuries barely lived in. Artisan urns covered in dust. A lifetime of skill poured into paintings that hung on the wall as invisibly as wallpaper in a cheap motel.
I knew men like Thoroughbred. It was barely about the luxury. It was about making and taking money, and spending it, and moving on.

For all that, his own personal estate wasn't that big. He'd been notoriously reclusive, when he wanted to be alone. But from here, that man's fingers creeped across the city, and his godforsaken lyrics spread into dusty corners of the internet like so many nihilistic cobwebs.

More than that, the place stank with crime. Thoroughbred had been a crook and a rabblerouser, a shaman of sinners, lighting the way for other scum to sink their teeth into Las Borpas and get fat off its flesh. He wasn't the only one, but he was one of the richest.

I found pieces of evidence, whispers and rumors. Some witnesses never made it to the courtroom. The ones that did changed their stories. I couldn't make anything stick.

Looks like something finally stuck after all.
After a few seconds of soaking in the ambience, Olivia turned to me.
Notice anything, John?
I glanced around, then to her.
You got a haircut.
That got a chuckle, at least. Eased some of that crime scene tension.
Just making sure you're sharp.
You think I've gone soft?
Not quite. But from here it smells you like you brushed your teeth with a bottle this morning.
The whiskey. Yeah. She'd notice that in a heartbeat. Anybody with a nose would. I didn't say anything to that.
No forced entry. Not down here, anyway.
Not anywhere we can see.
So Thoroughbred knew the perp.
Or let them in himself.
Wow! John Souls! Awesome!
Just like that I knew the voice. Older than I remember, but still that same goddamn voice, and it pierced my hangover just like it perforated my eardrums.
Jesse. Been awhile.
God that kid's eyes are creepy.
It sure has! Wow! But guess what! I'm a cop now!
You've got a badge, kid. But that alone doesn't make you a cop.
W-what? I-impossible!
He's right, Jesse. You're on the force, but you've still got a lot to learn.
Nnh...
What the hell kind of noise was that for an adult to make?

Damn, but I felt bad for the kid. Maybe I was getting soft, but he reminded me of Little Billy, still wide eyed, looking at the lights in the city instead of the darkness. Las Borpas was going to chew him up and spit him out, voracious for innocence and always hungry for more.
Was I ever like that? I must have been. Learning the truth about this city--and myself--wouldn't have hurt so bad, if I wasn't.
Hey, don't take it personally. You're here now, and you've got a hell of a sister to learn from. She's one of the best.
Yeah! And one day, I'm gonna be the chief of police!
Sure kid. Dream big.
Well, if you wanna help an old bum like me crack this case...
Sure thing Mister Souls! I'm ready for anything!
Coffee. Black as night mode.
Nnnhhh....
He slunk off to the kitchen. To her credit, Olivia waited until he was out of earshot to laugh.
Take it easy on him, John.
I knew she agreed. But she was soft for the kid.
Yeah, yeah. Enough yapping. Fill me in.
Thoroughbred was found dead in his office this morning, called in by the groundskeeper. Looked like trauma to the head, multiple strikes. Something thin and metal, but durable.
You don't have the weapon?
Hasn't been found yet. We're still combing the scene.
And you want an old nose like mine sniffing around, getting in the way?
If it picks up any new smells. Besides, it's better than you getting up to trouble on your own somewhere. I want you where I can see you.
Careful Olivia, I'm a married man.
I'll believe that when I finally see that mythical wife and child of yours.
She definitely exists and is completely real. As is my son, Little Billy, who is real.

She was about to reply when Jesse came back from the kitchen with my coffee. He handed it to me like a puppy with a new toy.

God help me but I wanted to kick him.
Here's your coffee, Mister Souls. Sorry it took so long, the cook wouldn't stop trying to get me to eat his spring rolls.
Oh yeah, the cook is here. With some other guests, it turns out.
Now that was news.
You two stay out here. I'm gonna have a little chat with this cook.
